source.name: Oracle Use Cases in Blockchain
source.instructions: Which of the following is NOT a common use case for blockchain oracles?

answers.answer: Providing real-world data for DeFi applications
Supplying random number generation for blockchain games
Directly executing smart contracts without external input
Verifying off-chain events for insurance claims

source.guidance: The correct answer is "Directly executing smart contracts without external input." This is not a use case for blockchain oracles. Oracles are designed to provide external data to smart contracts, not to execute them directly. The other options are all valid use cases for oracles: they provide real-world data for DeFi applications, enable cross-chain communication, supply random numbers for blockchain-based games, and verify off-chain events for insurance claims. This question tests the student's understanding of the role and limitations of oracles in blockchain ecosystems, distinguishing between what oracles do (provide external data) and what they don't do (execute smart contracts independently).
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify and analyze common use cases for blockchain oracles
